awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: Collaborative Research: A Next-Generation SuperNova Early Warning System for Multimessenger Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
When a massive star reaches the end of its life, the core of the star collapses, producing a supernova. While visually spectacular, less than 1% of the energy in the supernova is released as visible light or as kinetic energy in the surrounding environment. Most of the energy from the supernova is carried away by neutrinos produced during the collapse of the core.  In contrast to photons, neutrinos interact only very weakly with matter.  They can therefore stream out of the supernova explosion without delay and thus arrive at Earth minutes to hours before the optical explosion may be visible. Detecting the first neutrinos from a supernova therefore provides an early alert to trigger further observations. The SuperNova Early Warning System (SNEWS) is a network of neutrino detectors around the world designed to provide automated early alerts for supernovae in our galaxy. While rare, a galactic supernova would provide a unique opportunity to study the physics of core-collapse supernova, as well as the properties of neutrinos. Alerts from SNEWS will enable observations of the earliest phases of the supernova for physicists and astronomers around the world. The SNEWS project works to engage amateur astronomers by involving them in this science, as they play an important role in optical observations of supernova.

This award supports a collaborative group from several institutions to upgrade the existing SNEWS real-time alert system to include new detectors, and to prepare to better exploit the collective capabilities of these detectors.  The team will model neutrino light curves and use those models to evaluate the expected signals in all available neutrino detectors.  They will develop optimal methods for prompt determination of the supernova direction using both neutrino interaction anisotropies, as well as inter-experiment triangulation algorithms which will be based on relative observed timing of the neutrino signals.  Prompt directional information will sharply improve the likelihood to detect the early onset of the light curve in multiple channels.  This is crucial not only for the understanding of supernova explosions, but also for many other areas of physics including astrophysics, nuclear physics, and particle physics.  Finally they will develop pre-supernova alerts based on the observation of the uptick in neutrino production that accompanies the final burning stages of a doomed star.  This proposal also supports involvement of the amateur astronomy community in this exciting area  of research, the creation of a topical planetarium show, as well as a smartphone app for use in education and alert dissemination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This SNEWS2.0 project is all about maintaining the unique capability of early detection of a nearby supernova via its neutrinos, making sure the astronomical community is in a good position to exploit any such early warning, and deploying new techniques to maximize the available science when it happens. Its big contribution will come when the supernova does.  However, in the meantime the project has produced the infrastructure for connecting the network of neutrino detectors to a central server that is capable of using their neutrino signals to form coincidence alerts, and then send that alert to the rest of the community.  The neutrinos detectors within the SNEWS2.0 network which are already in operation have connectability to the SNEWS2.0 system, while those which are not yet in operation have begun tests using prototype servers that will connect to their experimental data acquisition system.  Firedrill-style tests have begun for both sets of expeirments, while detectors in operation already have the ability to send individual detector signals to the server for early-time coincidence detection of a supernova.  The University of Houston group was involved in the implementation of new physics (the coherent elastic neutrino-nucles scattering channel) into the simulation code that is used by the project, as well as implementation of code that provides a backbone for the communications of the individual detectors with the coincidence server and how to form alerts based on the information coming from the detectors.  University of Houston graduate student Sebastian Torres-Lara was critical in this work, and was one of the lead coders for these aspects of the project.  He also was instrumental in helping to lead the firedrill-style tests of the system, which have now been carried out successfuly several times during the last year.  The SNEWS2.0 system is ready for recieving communications from individual detectors, forming a coincidence of those as necessary, and then sending out an alert about the coincidence detection to everyone who is capable of receiving the alerts from SNEWS2.0.  This enables all detectors to search their data closely to further enhance the alert confidence, as well as provide additional details for the triangulation of the supernova within the sky.  Ultimately the system is ready to provide an early warning of a supernova based on the neutrino signal, provide a direction from which the supernova is most likely to have happened, and thus giving the ability for both amateur and professional astronmers the time to turn their telescopes towards the direction of the supernova and watch it explode.
